event_text: Australia's Labor government announces its asylum seeker policy, that no one sent offshore will ever be settled in Australia and everyone who arrives by boat will be sent offshore. Regional resettlement arrangement is signed with Papua New Guinea.

Liberal-National Coalition wins government and Tony Abbott becomes prime minister. Part of his campaign has focused on hardline amendments to Australia's refugee policies. He becomes known for the mantra "stop the boats".
Operation Sovereign Borders begins. The Australian defence force works to prevent asylum seekers from reaching Australia by boat.

Protests begin in the Manus Island detention centre. Escalating pressure turns into riots, leaving one asylum seeker dead and 77 injured. Amnesty International calls for an immediate end to offshore processing.
Iranian asylum seeker Reza Barati, 24, dies on Manus after receiving fatal head wounds from staff during the riots. An official investigation into the unrest begins.
The first group of Nauru refugees are resettled in Australian communities on five-year refugee visas. Seven other asylum seekers are denied refugee status.
Sayed Ibrahim Hussein dies after getting caught in a rip in the Galab channel near Nauru.
The last asylum seekers are transferred to Nauru: 157 Tamils detained at sea.

Iranian asylum seeker Hamid Kehazaei, 24, dies in a Brisbane hospital from a severe case of septicemia. After applying for a visa for medical treatment in Australia, he remained on the island for an entire day owing to delays while the infection spread.

The Australian and Cambodian governments sign a controversial deal that allows asylum seekers detained on Nauru to be transferred to Cambodia. Concerns about corruption and Cambodia's financial stability spread fear among asylum seekers on Nauru.

Immigration minister Scott Morrison accuses Save the Children staff of encouraging asylum seekers to self-harm in order to cast doubt on Australia's refugee policies. Save the Children strongly denies all allegations of misconduct.

After more than a year in detention, Murtada Al Hosseini came to believe the dangerous situation in Iraq was preferable to the indefinite trials of Manus Island. He decided to leave the only way it was possible to at the time: by returning home.
Ten men become the first to be given refugee status on Manus Island in a "milestone" decision to grant one-year temporary protection visas. They will stay at an open facility in East Lorengau.
Last person transferred to Papua New Guinea.

Scott Morrison agrees that babies born to asylum seekers in Australia on or before 4 December 2014 and their families can have protection claims assessed under the Australian system. They will not need to return to Nauru.
Peter Dutton succeeds Scott Morrison as Australia's new immigration minister. He for a system that does not favour the intake of migrants.

As one of the first refugees released into the Nauru community in 2015,  Nur Mohammed was assaulted and robbed. But he worked whatever jobs he could find to survive and in the hope of one day seeing the eight year old daughter he’d never met.
Open centre arrangements are introduced on Nauru. An end to detention on the island and the processing of all remaining asylum seekers are considered.

The Moss review is released, revealing numerous cases of sexual abuse in the Nauru detention centre. No evidence is found confirming Scott Morrison's accusations of misconduct by Save the Children staff.
The Australian Border Force Act 2015 takes effect, prohibiting workers, including health professionals, teachers and volunteers, from leaking information about conditions within detention.
Malcolm Turnbull becomes prime minister. Although he acknowledges the importance of the refugee situation, he does not suggest any immediate policy change.
Asylum seekers on Nauru are granted full freedom of movement. The decision comes just 48 hours before a high court case that would have ruled on the legality of offshore detention procedures.
The federal government offers welfare contract to Transfield Services, meaning the end to Save the Children's time on Nauru.

Ali Kharsa still thinks about the people he left on Nauru, half a decade after he was able to start a new life in Canada.“A lot of those people were my friends,” says the Syrian refugee. “I wanted to see them out of detention.”

The high court decision in the M68 asylum seeker case is handed down and the #LetThemStay campaign begins. It is now confirmed that Australian can legally send asylum seekers to detention in foreign countries. Rallies are held in Australian cities, demanding that the government allow 267 asylum seekers to stay on the mainland.

PNG's supreme court deems Australia's offshore detention procedures on Manus Island illegal. The PNG and Australian governments are ordered to immediately begin removing all asylum seekers from the centres.
Iranian asylum seeker Omid Masoumali, 23, dies in a Brisbane hospital after setting himself on fire on Nauru. It took officials 24 hours to transfer him to Brisbane for treatment.
The Manus Island detention centre is declared open in response to the PNG court's judgment on the illegality of offshore processing in the country.

Bangladeshi refugee Rakib Khan dies after seeking medical treatment in a Nauru hospital but before he could be medically transferred to Australia. He is the fifth man to have died in an offshore detention centre.
Pakistani asylum seeker Kamil Hussain, 34, drowns in a waterfall on Manus Island. Australia refuses to cover the cost of returning his body to his family.

Guardian Australia releases the Nauru files – more than 2,000 classified reports of sexual abuse, physical assaults and child abuse on Nauru. They reveal the federal government's inability to report and manage problems within offshore detention centres.
Malcolm Turbull announces that those processed as refugees on Manus Island and Nauru will now be elligible for resettlement in the US.
Faysal Ishak Ahmed, 27, dies in a Brisbane hospital after a fall and subsequent seizure on Manus Island.

Betelhem Zeleke doesn’t know why she was finally released from the Brisbane Immigration Transit Accommodation [BITA]. After more than three years in detention, the Ethiopian refugee was suddenly free to go: “They just told me ‘Get out from [here]’.

Iranian asylum seeker Hamed Shamshiripour dies of a suspected suicide on Manus Island. Despite requests from his friends to the Australian government for mental health support, Hamed received no treatment.
Fifty-two refugees on Manus and Nauru leave to be resettled in the US as part of the 2016 resettlement deal. But Washington announces possible plans to further reduce its refugee intake.
Sri Lankan asylum seeker Rajeev Rajendran, 34, dies by suicide on Manus Island.

The Refugee Processing Centre on Manus Island is forcibly closed after being classified as illegal by the PNG government. More than 700 men are left with nowhere to go as they remain banned from Australia and unwelcome in PNG.
A 29-year-old Bangladeshi man is killed in a motorcycle collision on Nauru.
Rohingya refugee Salim Kyawning, 52, dies after jumping off a moving bus. Concerns rise about the increase in suicides and suicide attempts on Manus Island.
Despite having continuously asked for psychiatric help, Fariborz Karami, 26, dies by suicide in the detention centre on Nauru.

Scott Morrison becomes prime minister. An opinion piece in Guardian Australia describes him as "someone who is willing, at times, to barter with the fate of the most vulnerable simply to get his way".
The last four children detained on Nauru leave the island for resettlement in the US. The US has resettled approximately 500 refugees from Australian-run offshore detention centres since late 2016.
The medevac bill becomes law. The purpose of the bill is to improve the process by which sick asylum seekers are given medical treatment in Australia.

Mehdi Savari wanted to entertain his fellow detainees on Manus. But security guards told him to stop his performances. This is a prison, not a party, he remembers being told. Now he’s trying to make his way in the USA

“I say to the psychiatrists, ‘If you want a good treatment for me, I should be released. Then I will be alright,” says Thanush Selvarasa, who was medevaced to Melbourne last year but is still in detention. “They say, ‘We don’t have the power – that decision is made by another hand’.”
Sayed Mirwais Rohani, a 32-year-old doctor, dies in Brisbane after being transferred from Manus Island. He is the 13th person to die while in the offshore processing system.
Behrouz Boochani, the "voice of Manus Island", escapes to New Zealand. The acclaimed writer vows never to return to PNG.
The medevac law is repealed.

Hamid Reza Shakib found himself in a “green hell” on Manus Island. But after a brutal second spell in detention, the UN stepped in. A week later, he was accepted as a refugee and then flown to France. It was the first time he felt safe.

Of the 3,127 people who sought sanctuary between July 2013 and December 2014 and were then sent offshore, almost half are still in limbo. About 300 remain offshore, split between Manus and Nauru, while more than 1,000 are in Australia after being evacuated for medical treatment or accompanying someone sick. Hundreds remain in detention in Australia while others have been released into the community on strict conditions. More than 750 have returned voluntarily to their home states, while 20 were forcibly deported. Around 900 have settled in a third country including 870 in the US. And 13 are dead.
